metadata.titleEn: China historical and future projected runoff and evapotranspiration dataset (1985-2100)
metadata.description: China historical (1985~2014) and future projected (2015~2100) 0.25° runoff and evapotranspiration dataset, simulated by the variable infiltration capacity (VIC) hydrological model which forcing by six CMIP6 models (CanESM5, FGOALS-g3, GFDL-CM4, IPSL-CM6A-LR, MPI-ESM1-2-HR and MRI-ESM2-0) with statistical downscaling, including three variables: total runoff, surface runoff and evapotranspiration, the time resolution is month or year. The downscaling bias-corrected models perform good in climatic simulation for China, and the VIC model forcing by observed meteorological dataset perform well in the historical runoff simulation. This dataset can be useful for the research about China’s future water resources change under mid (SSP2-4.5) and high (SSP5-8.5) warming scenarios.
metadata.instructions:
File name: data stored in .nc format, the file name is “./vars/XX/models/periods/vars_VIC_periods_yyyy_XX.nc”, in which "vars" represent the variables (“totrunoff” is total runoff, “surrunoff” is surface runoff, “evap” is evapotranspiration, units are all “m/day”), "models" represent GCMs, "periods" represent the periods or scenarios, “yyyy" represent the year; such as "./surrunoff/Monthly/CanESM5/ssp245/surrunoff_VIC_ssp245_2015_monthly.nc" represents the .nc file describes the monthly surface runoff in China under SSP2-4.5 scenarios in 2015 from the CanESM5 model. 
Method to read data: all files can use the "ncdump" command to read detail information, and can also read them with MATLAB, Python, cdo or nco tool, besides, these files not only include the corresponding variable, but also has the latitude and longitude variable. If you want to view the file in the form of picture, you can use the ArcGIS to open it.

literatureList.titleEn: Projection of China’s future runoff based on the CMIP6 mid-high warming scenarios

literatureList.titleEn: Estimation of future runoff in China based on CMIP6 mid-to-high temperature rise scenarios.

background: The Sixth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC AR6) indicates that the Earth’s mean temperature has increased by 1.1°C relative to the preindustrial revolution period of 1850–1900 and that the rate of increase in global surface temperature in the period of 1970–2020 is greater than that in any 50-year period prior to 2000. Large amounts of greenhouse gases emitted by human activities are a primary cause of global warming (IPCC, 2021); furthermore, elevated CO2 concentrations cause plant stomata to close, leading to reduced transpiration and thus affecting river flows (Gedney et al., 2006). Studies have shown (Skliris et al., 2016) that a 1°C increase will affect the hydrological cycle, amplifying the ambient humidity at a rate of 3–4%. Global climate models (GCMs) can describe in detail the changes in atmospheric motion, heat exchange, and sea-land-air-ice interactions over time (Gleick, 1989) and are effective tools for studying the effects of historical, present, and future atmospheric changes on surface physical processes (Gonzalez et al., 2010; Sun et al., 2013; Guo et al., 2015). Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 6 (CMIP6) has improved the simulation of temperature and precipitation in the China region compared with Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5 (CMIP5) (Jiang et al., 2020); specifically, the dry bias is significantly reduced in southern China (Zhu et al., 2020). CMIP6 is based on the Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) of CMIP5 (van Vuuren et al., 2011) and proposes the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) (Riahi et al., 2017), which can reflect newer and more diverse greenhouse gas concentration changes under social development (O’Neill et al., 2016). However, the spatial resolution of GCMs is coarse, and downscaling bias correction is usually required for finer-resolution basin-scale hydrological model simulations, where statistical downscaling is more widely used than dynamical downscaling due to simpler calculations and more reliable results (Ahmed et al., 2013).

The downscaling methods of GCMs mainly include dynamic downscaling and statistical downscaling. Although the former has clear physical meaning, it is more computationally intensive, while the latter is relatively easy to calculate and can correct the statistical bias of the GCMs with better results, so it is widely used in research regarding the impact of climate change at the regional scale (Sun et al., 2013; Zhang et al., 2016; Xu and Wang, 2019). Teutschbein and Seibert (2012) used different statistical methods to correct the precipitation and temperature of regional climate models for five mesoscale basins in Switzerland and found that the method based on the cumulative distribution function (CDF) was the most effective. Based on this result, Li et al. (2010) proposed the equidistant cumulative distribution function method (EDCDFm), which corrects the CDF of the GCM variables to be consistent with the measured data in the historical period, and the GCM output of the future scenario is corrected according to the difference between the CDF of the GCMs historical period and the measured data. The study shows that EDCDFm can effectively capture the extreme values of climate elements and improve the accuracy of the GCMs and model simulation after downscaling.

Generally, a value of NSE closer to 1 indicates that the simulation results are better, and an NSE less than 0 indicates that the simulation results are unreliable. The NSE of monthly streamflow between simulations and observations is at or above 0.60 at each station (Table 2), suggesting that the VIC model is more applicable to hydrological simulations in China.
research objective: In this paper, we use the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) to perform downscaling and bias correction in daily precipitation, daily maximum temperature, and daily minimum temperature for six CMIP6 models based on the historical gridded data from the high-resolution China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD). We use the bias-corrected precipitation, temperature, and daily mean wind speed to drive the variable infiltration capacity (VIC) hydrological model, and study the changes in multiyear average annual precipitation, annual evapotranspiration and total annual runoff depth relative to the historical baseline period (1985–2014) for the Chinese mainland, basins and grid scales in the 21st century future under the SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5 scenarios.

This study, based on the VIC hydrological model, uses six CMIP6 GCMs (CanESM5, FGOALS-g3, GFDL-CM4, IPSL-CM6A-LR, MPI-ESM1-2-HR, and MRI-ESM2-0) data with EDCDFm statistical downscaling bias-corrected and two future scenarios, SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5, to project future changes in the terrestrial surface water cycle in the Chinese mainland and major basins in the 21st century, using CMFD gridded data as a historical reference.
methods: In this paper, we use the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) to perform downscaling and bias correction in daily precipitation, daily maximum temperature, and daily minimum temperature for six CMIP6 models based on the historical gridded data from the high-resolution China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD). We use the bias-corrected precipitation, temperature, and daily mean wind speed to drive the variable infiltration capacity (VIC) hydrological model, and study the changes in multiyear average annual precipitation, annual evapotranspiration and total annual runoff depth relative to the historical baseline period (1985–2014) for the Chinese mainland, basins and grid scales in the 21st century future under the SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5 scenarios.

Therefore, this study used the EDCDFm method, CMFD and the six GCMs, which were first downscaled (DS) to 0.25° spatial resolution by bilinear interpolation; the daily Tmax, daily Tmax, and daily P of each GCM grid were then biased corrected (BC) based on the CDF of the corresponding grid series. The CDF was calculated by referring to the paper (Watterson, 2008; Li et al., 2010), where the probability density function (PDF) of temperature was estimated using a four-parameter beta function, the PDF of precipitation was estimated using a mixed gamma distribution function, and the parameters were estimated using the 1979–2014 series for the historical period and the 2015–2100 series for the future period. Three indicators were used to evaluate the downscaling bias-corrected GCMs data accuracy in monthly values: mean absolute error (MAE), root mean squared error (RMSE), and Pearson correlation coefficient (PCC).
dataset: The CMFD dataset spans 1979–2018 and includes seven elements: near-surface air temperature, surface pressure, specific humidity, wind speed, downward shortwave radiation, downward longwave radiation and precipitation rate, with a temporal resolution of 3 h and a spatial resolution of 0.1°. The daily precipitation rate, daily near-surface maximum temperature, daily near-surface minimum temperature, and daily near-surface wind speed of CMFD in 1979–2014 were interpolated to 0.25° by the bilinear interpolation method and as the measured information for the VIC model atmospheric drive and GCM bias correction.

Measured streamflow was used as references to evaluate the monthly simulation performance of the VIC and CaMa-Flood model; these measurements represented 15 hydrological stations in ten major river basins of China based on data from the Ministry of Water Resources and the Yingluoxia hydrological station (Figure 1 and Table 2) in the Hei Basin based on data from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center (Liu et al., 2016a, 2016b; Xie, 2016).
findings: The study shows that the VIC model accurately simulates runoff in major Chinese basins; the model data accuracy improves substantially after downscaling bias correction; and the future multimodel-mean multiyear average annual precipitation, annual evapotranspiration, and total annual runoff depth for the Chinese mainland and each basin increase relative to the historical period in near future (2020–2049) and far future (2070–2099) under the SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5 scenarios.

In summary, the hydrological station monthly streamflow based on CMFD and VIC model simulations had small errors and strong correlations with the observation streamflow in all basins, and the VIC model and CMFD driver used in this study performed well in the Chinese mainland (Table 2).

The monthly streamflow simulated by the CMFD-driven VIC model and CaMa-Flood model has NSEs of 0.6 in the YR and Huai basins and NSEs of 0.7–0.9 in other study basins, indicating that the VIC model hydrological simulation is applicable in the Chinese mainland. The hydrological projections of the single GCM data at the basin scale have large uncertainties. The multi-GCM arithmetic ensemble mean reduces the uncertainty of GCM projections. Under the SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5 scenarios, the future water resources in the Chinese mainland and each basin are likely to increase, and the decrease in annual runoff is likely to occur mainly in the northwest and southwest regions, which can provide a strong scientific reference for future water resource management and risk analysis in China under climate change.

Verification.Question: Does the application of the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) effectively improve the accuracy of downscaled climate data for hydrological simulations?
Is the variable infiltration capacity (VIC) hydrological model considered suitable for simulating streamflow in the Chinese mainland?
Can the CMFD dataset be used as a historical reference for bias correction in climate model simulations?

Disjunctive.Question: Which spatial resolution is typically used for downscaling GCM data for regional hydrological simulations, 0.1° or 0.25°?

Concept Completion.Question: What is the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) used for in data collection?
Where can one find the CMFD dataset, and what are its characteristics?
When are statistical downscaling methods preferred over dynamic downscaling in research?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to ensure the accuracy of hydrological simulations in the context of climate change projections for China?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to ensure accuracy in hydrological simulations is the use of the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) for downscaling and bias correction of daily precipitation, maximum temperature, and minimum temperature data from six CMIP6 models, based on historical gridded data from the high-resolution China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD).

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered when using global climate model outputs for basin-scale hydrological simulations?
Example.Answer: A challenge encountered is the coarse spatial resolution of global climate models (GCMs), which necessitates downscaling bias correction for finer-resolution basin-scale hydrological model simulations. This is typically addressed using statistical downscaling methods, which are preferred over dynamic downscaling due to simpler calculations and more reliable results.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that has been used to drive hydrological models for simulating streamflow in major Chinese river basins?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset is the CMFD dataset, which spans from 1979 to 2018, including elements like near-surface air temperature, pressure, specific humidity, wind speed, and precipitation rate, with a temporal resolution of 3 hours and a spatial resolution of 0.1°. This dataset is used to drive the Variable Infiltration Capacity (VIC) hydrological model and perform GCM bias correction.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the data collection methods used to obtain historical and future runoff and evapotranspiration data in the field of hydrology?
Feature Specification.Answer: CanESM5, FGOALS-g3, GFDL-CM4, IPSL-CM6A-LR, MPI-ESM1-2-HR, MRI-ESM2-0, Variable Infiltration Capacity hydrological model, Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method, China Meteorological Forcing Dataset

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the CMFD dataset used in hydrological modeling?
Feature Specification.Answer: spans from 1979 to 2018, near-surface air temperature, surface pressure, specific humidity, wind speed, downward shortwave radiation, downward longwave radiation, precipitation rate, temporal resolution of 3 hours, spatial resolution of 0.1°, interpolated to 0.25° resolution

Feature Specification.Question: What are the features of statistical downscaling methods used for climate model data in hydrological studies?
Feature Specification.Answer: easy to calculate, more reliable than dynamic downscaling, bias correction of daily precipitation, bias correction of daily maximum temperature, bias correction of daily minimum temperature, corrections made according to the cumulative distribution function of historical grid series data

Quantification.Question: How many CMIP6 models were utilized to simulate the future terrestrial surface water cycle in the Chinese mainland?
What is the temporal resolution of the CMFD dataset used for atmospheric drive and bias correction?

Definition.Question: What is the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) used for in hydrological modeling?
Definition.Answer: The Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) is used for downscaling and bias correction in daily precipitation, daily maximum temperature, and daily minimum temperature for global climate models. It corrects the CDF of these variables to be consistent with measured data during the historical period, enhancing the accuracy of future scenario projections.

Definition.Question: What does statistical downscaling involve in the context of global climate model simulations?
Definition.Answer: Statistical downscaling involves correcting the statistical bias of global climate models (GCMs) using historical data to achieve finer-resolution simulations. This method is computationally less intensive than dynamic downscaling and provides more reliable results for regional climate change impact studies.

Comparison.Question: How do the downscaling methods of Global Climate Models (GCMs) differ in terms of computational intensity and applicability for regional climate impact studies?
Comparison.Answer: The downscaling methods of GCMs mainly include dynamic downscaling and statistical downscaling. Dynamic downscaling has a clear physical meaning but is more computationally intensive, whereas statistical downscaling is easier to calculate and can correct the statistical bias of the GCMs with better results, making it more widely used in regional climate impact research.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in spatial resolution and data sources between the CMFD dataset and the downscaled GCMs used in hydrological simulations?
Comparison.Answer: The CMFD dataset has a spatial resolution of 0.1°, while the downscaled GCMs used in hydrological simulations are interpolated to a spatial resolution of 0.25°. The CMFD dataset spans 1979–2018 and includes seven elements, serving as historical gridded data for bias correction, whereas the GCMs are used for projecting future changes.

Interpretation.Question: How might the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) influence the interpretation of historical precipitation and temperature data when applied to downscale global climate models (GCMs)?
Interpretation.Answer: The EDCDFm method is used to correct the statistical bias of GCM variables by aligning their cumulative distribution functions with observed data during the historical period. This approach allows for a more accurate representation of extreme climate elements and enhances the reliability of simulations, providing a more precise understanding of historical climate patterns.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the need for downscaling and bias correction in hydrological modeling using GCM data in the context of Chinese regional climate studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The coarse spatial resolution of GCMs necessitates downscaling and bias correction for finer-resolution basin-scale hydrological model simulations. Statistical downscaling is often preferred due to its simpler calculations and ability to correct the statistical bias of the GCMs effectively. This approach helps to improve the accuracy of climate simulations at the regional scale, where climate models like CMIP6 have shown reduced simulation errors in the China region.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) favored for correcting precipitation and temperature data in regional climate models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The EDCDFm is favored because it effectively captures the extreme values of climate elements and improves the accuracy of GCMs after downscaling. This method adjusts the cumulative distribution function (CDF) of GCM variables to align with historical measured data, allowing for improved bias correction of future scenario outputs. The method is particularly effective in producing reliable downscaled outputs for regional applications.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the multi-GCM ensemble approach to be beneficial in reducing uncertainties in hydrological projections for future climate scenarios?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Hydrological projections using single GCM data at the basin scale can have large uncertainties. By using the multi-GCM arithmetic ensemble mean, these uncertainties are reduced. This approach aggregates multiple model outputs, which helps to provide a more reliable estimate of future water resources and climate impacts, thus offering a stronger scientific basis for future water resource management and risk analysis under climate change scenarios.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using statistical downscaling methods on the accuracy of hydrological simulations in regional climate studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Statistical downscaling methods, such as the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm), are used to correct the statistical bias of Global Climate Models (GCMs). These methods improve the accuracy of hydrological simulations by providing finer-resolution data that better reflects local conditions. As a result, the accuracy of model simulations, including variables like precipitation, temperature, and runoff, is enhanced, leading to more reliable projections of hydrological changes.

Causal Consequence.Question: How do different emission scenarios like SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5 affect the projections of future water resources in China?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of different emission scenarios such as SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5 influences the projections of future water resources by impacting the expected changes in climate variables like precipitation and temperature. Under these scenarios, the study projects an increase in multiyear average annual precipitation, annual evapotranspiration, and total annual runoff depth for the Chinese mainland and each basin. These changes are likely to enhance water resource availability in the future, although variations may occur regionally, with potential decreases in annual runoff in the northwest and southwest regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact of using a high-resolution gridded dataset, like the CMFD, on the evaluation of hydrological model performance?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing a high-resolution gridded dataset like the China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD) significantly impacts the evaluation of hydrological model performance by providing detailed baseline data against which model outputs can be compared. The CMFD offers high temporal and spatial resolution, which helps in accurately driving hydrological models and correcting biases in GCM outputs. Consequently, the model simulation results, such as monthly streamflow, show strong correlations with observed data, enhancing confidence in the model's applicability for future projections in the region.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are involved in applying the Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) for downscaling and bias correction of climate model data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The application of the EDCDFm involves first downscaling the GCM data to a higher spatial resolution using bilinear interpolation. Subsequently, the CDF of the GCM variables is corrected to match the measured data from the historical period. The GCM output for future scenarios is then corrected based on the differences between the historical CDF of the GCMs and the measured data. This procedure includes estimating the probability density function (PDF) of temperature using a four-parameter beta function and precipitation using a mixed gamma distribution function.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are taken to ensure the accuracy of hydrological simulations in major Chinese basins using downscaled climate model outputs?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure accuracy, the procedural steps include using statistical downscaling methods like EDCDFm to correct biases in GCM outputs, and then using these corrected outputs to drive the VIC hydrological model. The accuracy of the model is evaluated using indicators such as the Nash-Sutcliffe efficiency (NSE), mean absolute error (MAE), root mean squared error (RMSE), and Pearson correlation coefficient (PCC) by comparing simulated streamflow against observed data from hydrological stations across major river basins.

Expectation.Question: What might be the anticipated challenges in using statistical downscaling methods for correcting GCM data biases in regional climate studies?
Expectation.Answer: The anticipated challenges could include ensuring the accuracy of the bias-correction methods like EDCDFm in capturing extreme climate events, as well as dealing with the computational intensity and reliability of the chosen statistical techniques compared to dynamic methods.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be an expectation of increased accuracy in hydrological simulations when using a multi-GCM ensemble mean approach?
Expectation.Answer: The expectation of increased accuracy arises because the multi-GCM ensemble mean approach can reduce the uncertainties inherent in individual GCM projections, providing a more reliable average that is likely to better represent future scenarios.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected improvements in the accuracy of hydrological model simulations after applying statistical downscaling bias correction to GCM data?
Expectation.Answer: The expected improvements include a substantial increase in model data accuracy, as downscaling bias correction can adjust the GCM data to better match historical observations, thus enhancing the simulation of runoff and other hydrological variables.

Judgmental.Question: How do researchers perceive the role of statistical downscaling in addressing spatial resolution limitations of Global Climate Models (GCMs) in hydrological studies?
Judgmental.Answer: Researchers consider statistical downscaling as a valuable approach to address the coarse spatial resolution of Global Climate Models (GCMs). It is preferred over dynamic downscaling due to simpler calculations and more reliable results. Statistical downscaling corrects the bias of GCMs, making it widely used for studying the impact of climate change on regional scales, including hydrological simulations in China.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the spatial and temporal resolution of datasets can affect the accuracy of hydrological simulations in regional studies.
Assertion.Answer: The spatial resolution of 0.25° and temporal resolution of monthly or yearly data are crucial in hydrological simulations as they determine the granularity and precision of the model outputs. Finer resolutions allow for more detailed simulations that better capture local variations in hydrology, leading to improved accuracy in modeling runoff and evapotranspiration patterns.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the significance of using multiple climate models and scenarios in projecting future water resource changes.
Assertion.Answer: Using multiple climate models and scenarios, like the six CMIP6 models and SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5 scenarios, helps to capture a range of possible future conditions and reduces uncertainty in projections. This approach provides a more comprehensive understanding of potential changes in water resources and helps in assessing the implications of different greenhouse gas emission pathways.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the methods used for downscaling and bias correction in climate model simulations and evaluate their applicability to hydrological modeling in regional studies.
Request/Directive.Answer: The Equidistant Cumulative Distribution Function method (EDCDFm) is used for downscaling and bias correction in daily precipitation, daily maximum temperature, and daily minimum temperature for six CMIP6 models, based on historical gridded data from the high-resolution China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD). This method corrects the cumulative distribution function of GCM variables to align with measured data from the historical period and then applies this correction to future scenarios. This approach is widely used due to its computational efficiency and ability to correct statistical biases, making it suitable for regional hydrological modeling.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that could supplement existing hydrological models to improve the accuracy of future water resource projections under different climate scenarios.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets that could enhance hydrological model accuracy include high-resolution historical climate data like the China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD), which provides detailed information on air temperature, pressure, humidity, wind speed, and radiation, among others. Additionally, measured streamflow data from major hydrological stations in China, as mentioned in the study, could be used to validate and refine model simulations. Incorporating such datasets can improve bias correction and the accuracy of projections under scenarios like SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5.
